title: Anton Schall
text:
Anton Schall (22 June 1907 – 5 August 1947) was an <a href="Austrians">Austrian</a> <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a> who played for the celebrated Austrian national side of the early 1930s that became known as the "<a href="Wunderteam">Wunderteam</a>". He also played for <a href="VfB%20Admira%20Wacker%20M%C3%B6dling">Admira Vienna</a>, and later managed <a href="FC%20Basel">FC Basel</a>. Normally a versatile left footed forward or winger, Schall is considered one of the greatest Austrian footballers. A pacy, skillful forward, Schall possessed fine finishing and great attacking intelligence. Later in his career Schall played as a defender.
His succes with the national team included making Runner-up at the <a href="1927-30%20Central%20European%20International%20Cup">1927-30 Central European International Cup</a>, Winner at the <a href="1931-32%20Central%20European%20International%20Cup">1931-32 Central European International Cup</a> being top scorer for <a href="Austria%20national%20football%20team">Austria</a> & reaching the semifinals at the <a href="1934%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1934 FIFA World Cup</a>.
After his playing career, Schall, who suffered from a rare heart condition, moved to Switzerland and took over <a href="FC%20Basel">Basel</a> as club trainer in the <a href="1946%E2%80%9347%20FC%20Basel%20season">1946–47 season</a>. Schall led Basel to win the <a href="Swiss%20Cup">Swiss Cup</a>, 3–0 in the final against <a href="Lausanne%20Sports">Lausanne Sports</a>. However, he died shortly afterwards aged 40 during a workout on the football field. Team captain <a href="Ernst%20Hufschmid%20%28footballer%29">Ernst Hufschmid</a> then took Basel over as coach.
